keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five and life in prison.
Rossi faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities later debunked.
He was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit backlog, a result of Utah’s efforts to clear its unsolved cases.
Rossi fled to Scotland and was arrested there while receiving treatment for COVID-19, with hospital staff recognizing his tattoos from an Interpol notice.
He used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and was previously wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
The victim testified about being manipulated financially and emotionally, and subjected to a violent rape after a brief relationship.
The case highlights the dangers of false death claims by convicted sex offenders and the importance of DNA database use in solving cold cases.
Rossi's legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, and he has a history of sexual abuse and deception, including being a serial abuser of women.
Utah law allows prison sentences to be given as a range, with 'five years to life' being the maximum for first-degree rape.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man with a history of sexual abuse, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to five years to life in prison after being identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog. He faked his death in 2020 by claiming to have died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which authorities debunked. He fled to Scotland, where he was arrested while receiving treatment for COVID-19 after hospital staff recognized his distinctive tattoos, including one from Brown University. He was extradited to Utah in January 2024 and convicted in a second rape case in September 2025. The case highlights the dangers of false death claims by sex offenders and the importance of DNA databases and international cooperation in solving cold cases. Rossi, who used aliases like Arthur Knight, is considered a flight risk and a serial abuser, and the sentencing underscores the need for accountability and public safety.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
